node.title: Sweeping a State Variable Using PF
node.bodyText:
This question may be for more general MOOSE use, at the moment I have a PF simulation and one of the variables is an applied external electric potential V. Usually I run a transient simulation for a fixed V, however I would like to simulate to steady-state for say V = 0 to 1 in steps in 0.1 V.
Thank you.

Hello
Can you use a FunctionAux?
Is the variable a nonlienar variable or an auxiliary variable?
Guillaume

node.title: How to define the boundaries of 2D slice cut from 3D model
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSEers,
I run a 3D simulation first, and cut a cross-section using 'slice' function in paraview to get a 2D model. Then I want to run simulation on the 2D slice with mesh of the slice using FileMesh, but how to define the boundaries of it?  I tried to use boundaries such as "left right..." directly, but the error pop up as follow. Thanks.

the following node sets (ids) do not exist on the mesh: left (1), right (2)

If you know how to write the geometry of the slice mathematically you can use ParsedGenerateSideset with FileMeshGenerator. You can extract whatever postprocessor value you need from there. You might also be able to run a simulation only on that slice by defining it as a block with SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator (I haven't tried this, but give it a shot)
[Mesh]
  [name_1]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = <meshfile>
  []
  [name_2]
    type = ParsedGenerateSideset
    input = name_1
    combinatorial_geometry =<parsed expression for slice e.g '((z > 0-1e-8) & (z < 0+1e-8))' for a slice at z = 0>
    new_sideset_name =<what_you_want_to_call it>
  []
[]
thanks. @richmondodufisan

Hello
Once you have extracted a slice using this technique, you can turn it into blcoks with this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator.html
then if you want to delete the rest use this first to create an independent mesh:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/BlockToMeshConverterGenerator.html
Guillaume

node.title: How stresses/strains are outputted?
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I'm working on postprocessing stresses/strains from MOOSE simulation. For each element, the stresses/strains are calculated at _qp points of an element. However, when output the stress/strain values using Auxkernel, a single value is outputted for an element. I wonder how this single value for an element is determined. Is this an "average" value based on the _qp values of an element? If so, what is the averaging algorithm? Also, is it possible to output all the values for all the _qp points of an element?
Thanks for the help.

How are you getting the output from an AuxKernel? To my understanding those just tell MOOSE what to calculate for an AuxVariable over the domain that variable is defined.
On the other hand, a Postprocessor block is what I use to output what I need. If there's a single value being output maybe you can check that block of your input file and see if its a PointValue/NodalSum/ElementAverageValue etc? The full documentation of Postprocessor objects is here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Postprocessors/

Hello
So if using an AuxKernel, the output is based on the finite element family used for the auxiliary variables.
The value of the property is computed at all Qps then there is a least-square solve to pick the coefficients multiplying the shape functions for the variable. So essentially a projection happens under the hood.
By default we use constant monomials to output the material properties.  There are material property output parameters on each Material object
Guillaume

node.title: Extract Strain Rate from PorousFlowVolumetricStrain
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose community,
I'm actively developing and de-bugging a multi-dimensional HM model. The general concept is a 2D horizontal fracture plane embedded in a 3D volume using a conforming mesh generated with Gmsh, both represented as separate subdomains.
My understanding is that PorousFlowVolumetricStrain computes the principal and volumetric strain rates. Is it possible to have this material output the zz component of the strain rate at each time step / is there a minimal working example I can follow as a reference? Or is there a different / better approach I should be considering to output strain rates?

Hello
Use the output_properties parameter to trigger a material property output
If you need to find the name of the material properties first, you can get them from show_material_properties in the Debug block
Guillaume
Thank you @GiudGiud

node.title: Symbol Names in ParsedFunction
node.bodyText:
I am having to define functions similar to the one below for a large number of objects. I would like to define the constants used in this case as symbol_names as global parameters that do not have to be defined each and every time as in the below example. Is there a way to reduce the repitetion of constant value definition for each function that will have to be defined?
  [./p14displ_x]
    type = ParsedFunction 
    symbol_names = 'A P02 tau2 m xf zf yf xi_1 xi_2 Vmax t0 n'    
    symbol_values = '7.85e-7 1e6 2.0e-3 2.0e-6 4.77e-3 0.0 0.0 1.53e5 6.375e6 392.5 8.0e-4 2'           
    expression = 'if(t < t0*n, 1e-1*t+x, (A*P02*tau2/m*(1-exp(-(t0*n)/tau2))/xi_1*(1-exp(-xi_1*t))/Vmax)+x)'# x+(A*P02*tau2/m*(1-exp(-t/tau2)))*sin(cot((yf-y)/(xf-x))) #(A*P02*tau2/m*(1-exp(-t/tau2)))*sin(cot((yf-y)/(xf-x))))
  []

yes that is correct. So something like:
A = 7.85e-7
P02 = 1e6
....


...
[Functions]
   [./p14displ_x]
    type = ParsedFunction 
    symbol_names = 'A P02 ...'    
    symbol_values = '${A} ${P02} ...'           
    expression = 'if(t < t0*n, 1e-1*t+x, (A*P02*tau2/m*(1-exp(-(t0*n)/tau2))/xi_1*(1-exp(-xi_1*t))/Vmax)+x)'# x+(A*P02*tau2/m*(1-exp(-t/tau2)))*sin(cot((yf-y)/(xf-x))) #(A*P02*tau2/m*(1-exp(-t/tau2)))*sin(cot((yf-y)/(xf-x))))
  []
[]

node.title: Is the PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling kernel compulsory?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I’m conducting a Thermo-hydro-mechanical simulation using the porous flow module. I’m wondering whether the PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling kernel is compulsory for this simulation. When is it advisable to ignore it? Thanks.

Hello
If you remove this you are decoupling the thermo-hydro and the mechanical parts. The fluid pressure gradient stress term wont exist to affect the displacements.
Guillaume

node.title: Trouble with ParsedMaterial
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am using MOOSE to solve a Phase-Field problem but I have trouble with a ParsedMaterial.
You will find my code in the following. I got an error from the if condition in the material expected '=' after parameter name '0.03', got ','
I would like to define a variable kappa_psi depending on the value of the variable psi.
How can I correct my code?
I stay available
Thanks in advance
Regards
Alexandre
---------------------------------------------------

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 250
  ny = 250
  nz = 0
  xmin = -1.5
  xmax = 1.5
  ymin = -1.5
  ymax = 1.5
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]

[GlobalParams]
  outputs = exodus
[]

[Variables]
  active = 'psi'
  [./psi]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    [./InitialCondition]
      type = SmoothCircleIC
      invalue = 1
      outvalue = 0
      radius = 1
      x1 = 0
      y1 = 0
      int_width = 0.15
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  active = 'dpsidt ACBulk_psi ACInterface_psi'

  [./dpsidt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = psi
  [../]
  [./ACBulk_psi]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = psi
    mob_name = L_psi
    f_name = g_psi
  [../]
  [./ACInterface_psi]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = psi
    mob_name = L_psi
    kappa_name = kappa_psi
  [../]

[]

[Materials]
  active = 'consts var free_energy_psi'

  [./consts]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'L_psi'
    prop_values = '1'
  [../]

  [./free_energy_psi]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    block = 0
    f_name = g_psi
    args = 'psi'
    constant_names = 'A_psi B_psi C_psi'
    constant_expressions = '46.5 -83. 31.5'
    function = 'A_psi * psi^4+B_psi * psi^3+C_psi * psi^2'
    enable_jit = true
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]

  [./var]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = kappa_psi
    coupled_variables = 'psi'
    function = if(psi>0.5, 0.03, 0.01)
  [../]
[]


[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = 'bdf2'
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'

  l_max_its = 20
  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  l_abs_tol = 1.0e-6

  nl_max_its = 10
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-6

  start_time = 0.0
  end_time   = 1

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = SolutionTimeAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.1
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  exodus = true
[]
Can you try putting quotes around your function?
I tried with quotes function = 'if(psi>0.5, 0.03, 0.01)' but I get an error Invalid function if(psi>0.5, 0.03, 0.01) in ParsedMaterialHelper. Syntax error: Unknown identifier

You need to fix this line
function = 'A_psipsi^4+B_psipsi^3+C_psi*psi^2'

presumably you want a * between the psis in psipsi?
In the future please paste the whole error as that will make it easier to help you

Thanks for your answer. Unfortunately, the error is not coming from here (the * were here, github erased them editing my text).
You will find the whole error in the following.

*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
if(psi>0.5, 0.03, 0.01)
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier
Stack frames: 19
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >)
2: void mooseError<char const (&) [18], std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, char, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >&, char const (&) [27], char const*>(char const (&) [18], std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, char&&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >&, char const (&) [27], char const*&&)
3: ParsedMaterialHelper::functionParse(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > > > const&, std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > > > const&, std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > > > const&, std::vector<PostprocessorName, std::allocator > const&, std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > > > const&, std::vector<double, std::allocator > const&)
4: ParsedMaterialTempl::ParsedMaterialTempl(InputParameters const&)
5: /home/asacmora/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0(+0x15cc598) [0x7f8399bb3598]
6: Factory::create(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, InputParameters const&, unsigned int, bool)
7: /home/asacmora/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0(+0x120bfeb) [0x7f83997f2feb]
8: FEProblemBase::addMaterialHelper(std::vector<MaterialWarehouse*, std::allocator<MaterialWarehouse*> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, InputParameters&)
9: FEProblemBase::addMaterial(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, InputParameters&)
10: Action::timedAct()
11: ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)
12: ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions()
13: MooseApp::runInputFile()
14: MooseApp::run()
15: main
16: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(+0x29d90) [0x7f8391907d90]
17: __libc_start_main
18: /home/asacmora/projects/moose/modules/phase_field/phase_field-opt(+0x240f) [0x564355e1840f]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

It seems Moose does not recognize psi, even if it is declared in the coupled variables.
I ran your input yesterday. When I put quotes around 'if(psi>0.5, 0.03, 0.01)' and made the suggested edit to the other parsed function, it ran fine for me
Thanks for your time and your discussion.

node.title: Execution order of functions in UserObject and Material systems
node.bodyText:
I want to update material properties in each linear iteration of a PJFNK calculation. So a material object derived from GenericConstantMaterial is constructed, and the computeQpProperties() is dependent on a self-defined function's return value to update the material properties. The self-defined function is constructed in a UserObject object which is derived from ElementIntegralUserObject. What I want is running execute() method along all elements and gathering values in finalize() method in each linear iteration, then the self-defined function will return a correct value when it is called by computeQpProperties(). However, I found that the self-defined function was called before finalize() so I got a wrong return value checked in the debug mode.
Here is the related execution order:
      0 Linear |R| = 4.176985e+02
[DBG] Computing elemental user objects on LINEAR
[DBG] Ordering of User Objects on block 1
[DBG] Executing ElementUserObject on LINEAR
[DBG] Order of execution:
[DBG] sph
                             
[DBG] Only user objects active on local element/sides are executed
[DBG] Ordering of User Objects on block 2
[DBG] Executing ElementUserObject on LINEAR
[DBG] Order of execution:
[DBG] sph

Here is the related part in the input file:
[Materials]
  [openmc_mgxs]
    type = OpenMCXSMaterial
    indexed_by_subdomain_name = true
    openmc_userobject = openmc
    sph_userobject = sph
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [openmc]
    type = RunOpenMCUO
    mgxs_cell = 'fuel moderator'
   []
   [sph]
      type = SPHFactorUO
      openmc_userobject = openmc
      group_fluxes = 'group_1 group_2'
      execute_on = LINEAR
    []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

node.title: Installing HPC Version in a Singularity Container
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
i want to use the MOOSEFRAMEWORK on a HPC-Cluster which doesn't have the python development libraries installed and is not planning on doing so. I have currently a functioning version running with the conda environment, however in the installation guide it says that the HPC installation will perform better.
The HPC support refers me to using a singularity container, install the required packages there and use that to run the desired software.
However, I am not able to run the tests in the container after sucessfully compiling, as following traceback is produced (seems to have to do with python multiprocessing):
 ./run_tests -j 6
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./run_tests", line 8, in <module>
    TestHarness.buildAndRun(sys.argv, None, MOOSE_DIR)
  File "/root/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/TestHarness.py", line 180, in buildAndRun
    harness = TestHarness(argv, moose_dir, app_name=app_name, moose_python=moose_python)
  File "/root/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/TestHarness.py", line 342, in __init__
    self.initialize(argv, app_name)
  File "/root/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/TestHarness.py", line 924, in initialize
    self.scheduler = self.factory.create(scheduler_plugin, self, plugin_params)
  File "/root/projects/moose/python/FactorySystem/Factory.py", line 28, in create
    return self.objects[type](*args, **kwargs)
  File "/root/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/schedulers/RunParallel.py", line 27, in __init__
    Scheduler.__init__(self, harness, params)
  File "/root/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/schedulers/Scheduler.py", line 74, in __init__
    self.run_pool = ThreadPool(processes=self.available_slots)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 925, in __init__
    Pool.__init__(self, processes, initializer, initargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 196, in __init__
    self._change_notifier = self._ctx.SimpleQueue()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/context.py", line 113, in SimpleQueue
    return SimpleQueue(ctx=self.get_context())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/queues.py", line 336, in __init__
    self._rlock = ctx.Lock()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/context.py", line 68, in Lock
    return Lock(ctx=self.get_context())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/synchronize.py", line 162, in __init__
    SemLock.__init__(self, SEMAPHORE, 1, 1, ctx=ctx)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/synchronize.py", line 57, in __init__
    sl = self._semlock = _multiprocessing.SemLock(
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

Is there a known quick and easy way around this or is this to singularity-specific to be solved here?
@milljm

I have never encountered this error before. Seems to originate from within Python's multiprocessing package. But I don't know why that would be the case. What flavor of Linux did you base this container off of?
Also, I think we can get a real clean picture of what went into this container if you can supply the results of the following comand:
apptainer inspect --deffile yourcontainer.sif
Please look through the results before posting, and comment out anything you think may be sensitive.

edit: I am right now in the process of creating a new container and complete the whole process from scratch, will upload the results later on.
this just produces:
bootstrap: localimage
from: ubuntu-test/
I created the container using
$singularity build --sandbox ubuntu docker://ubuntu
$sudo singularity shell --writable ubuntu
I should mention i did this on two different machines using the ubuntu image above or the ubuntu20.04 image, respectively.
I followed the installation for both HPC Clusters and for Offline (air-gapped), the traceback is the same.

terminal_output.txt
This is the terminal output during the installation process until the first error regarding some issue with fortran-compiler. This was the point where I switched to using the build-essential gcc version as I was unable to fix the error.
